name: brainstorm
content:

(of a group of people) to suggest a lot of ideas for a future activity very quickly, before considering some of them more carefully: The team got together to brainstorm. I brainstorm with my colleagues to come up with new promotions and events. We brainstormed possible titles for the project. Related word
brainstorming
More examplesFewer examplesAfter 30 minutes of brainstorming we came up with the answer.We brainstorm about different dishes we could serve.Conference delegates get into groups to brainstorm marketing concepts.After brainstorming with my advisor, we came up with a method.It can be good to brainstorm a project over a drink.

mainly US (UK usually brainwave) a sudden clever idea: have a brainstorm The toy's inventor was watching his children play one day when he had a brainstorm. This was a brainstorm I came up with when I was driving. The concept was the brainstorm of a worker at the plant.

UK a sudden state of being unable to think clearly: have a brainstorm I must have had a brainstorm - I went shopping and forgot to take any money. It was a stupid brainstorm and it cost his team the victory.

/ˈbreɪnˌstɔr·mɪŋ/
We need to do some brainstorming before we get down to detailed planning.
a sudden, new idea that you are enthusiastic about: They got this brainstorm that they could make a living by buying and selling antiques.
Add to word list
Add to word list
MEETINGS to meet in a group to suggest a lot of new ideas very quickly, with the intention of considering them more carefully later: Engineers from all over the company met every couple of weeks to brainstorm. Remember all ideas are welcomed - so start brainstorming! A team will brainstorm a job description for the new leadership post.
a new, original idea or set of ideas: They have started to turn their brainstorm into a real product.
